raw_text:
Ireland 21-19 Argentina
 
 An injury-time dropped goal by Ronan O'Gara stole victory for Ireland from underneath the noses of Argentina at Lansdowne Road on Saturday.
 
 O'Gara kicked all of Ireland's points, with two dropped goals and five penalties, to give the home side a 100% record in their autumn internationals. An impressive Argentina appeared in control until the dying seconds. The Pumas shocked the Irish early on with a try from Federico Aramburu, and Felipe Contepomi kicked 14 points. The well-drilled and sharper Pumas out-played and out-thought Ireland in the early stages. Indiscipline allowed Argentina's Leinster fly-half Contepomi to open the scoring in the third minute with a straightforward penalty. He was on the mark again two minutes later when Argentina shocked a ragged Ireland with the first try of the game. Ireland turned the ball over and Manuel Contepomi broke through an unstructured defence before feeding his midfield partner Aramburu to sprint in under the posts. O'Gara finally got Ireland on the board with a dropped goal in the ninth minute only for Contepomi to rifle over his second penalty two minutes later. Playing into a strong wind and rain, Ireland continued to come second best in tight situations, and turnovers began to mount up against a rugged defence. O'Gara managed to land his second penalty in the 36th minute, but once again Contepomi replied in kind four minutes into first-half injury time. The second-half started as the first had ended. O'Gara rifled over another penalty in the 45th minute, but Contepomi matched it three minutes later. The upper-body strength of the Pumas never allowed Ireland to take control up front, while the three-quarters had no space to manoeuvre. Ireland had to rely on O'Gara's boot to keep in touch rather than any contrived running plays. The Munsterman landed two more penalties - one of them from 48 metres - to bring his team to within four points with 13 minutes on the clock remaining. And Ireland's chance came when Argentina's number eight Gonzalo Longo was yellow carded with six minutes to go for an offence in the line-out. O'Gara made no mistake as he rifled over his fifth penalty to set up a tense final few minutes. But Ireland showed great composure to get themselves into a position to allow O'Gara to thump over a massive drop goal to complete a tremendous, if fortuitous, comeback.
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland wins 21-19 against Argentina in the autumn internationals at Lansdowne Road with Ronan O'Gara kicking all of Ireland's points and scoring the winning dropped goal. 

Argentina initially controlled the game but were thwarted by discipline issues allowing Ireland to open the score. They then scored a try from Federico Aramburu and took an early lead through penalties.

Ireland continued to struggle against Argentina in tight situations, but managed to land two more penalties to keep the score 19-12 with minutes remaining. However, they were ultimately denied a win by Gonzalo Longo's yellow card on the last play of the match.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland won 21-19 against Argentina at Lansdowne Road, with Ronan O'Gara scoring all points including two dropped goals and five penalties. Argentina took an early lead but Ireland came back behind O'Gara's kicking. The match was played in rainy conditions, and Argentina controlled the game until a late yellow card for Gonzalo Longo gave Ireland a chance to score, culminating in a drop goal from O'Gara at injury time.
gemma2:2b: Ireland defeated Argentina 21-19 in an injury time drop goal by Ronan O'Gara.  Argentina started strong with a try and Contepomi kicked multiple penalties. Ireland struggled against Argentina's tight defence and were down at halftime. Despite a resilient Irish effort and some late penalty conversions, O'Gara sealed the victory for Ireland with a decisive drop goal.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A 100% Irish lead at Lansdowne Road against Argentina in their autumn internationals. Ronan O’Gara scored two dropped goals and five penalties for Ireland, while Federico Aramburu and Felipe Contepomi both kicked penalty attempts. The Pumas showed more control up front than Ireland during the match.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland defeated Argentina 21-19 in injury time at Lansdowne Road, with Ronan O'Gara scoring all of Ireland's points and kicking three dropped goals as the team secured their first consecutive autumn internationals win. Despite early success for Argentina, O'Gara outscored them by a point each and finished with five penalties and two dropped goals to give Ireland a 100% record in their autumn internationals despite being shut down by Argentina's physicality and strong defense throughout the game.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland clinched victory with Ronan O’Gara’s late dropped goal against Argentina 21-19 at Lansdowne Road. O’Gara scored all points (two dropped goals and five penalties) for Ireland. The game started favorably for Argentina due to early tries by Federico Aramburu and Felipe Contepomi, who kicked 14 points. Despite Irish turnovers, they managed to stay close thanks to O’Gara’s kicking. In the second half, Ireland capitalized on a yellow card for Longo, allowing O’Gara to secure his fifth penalty. With just over ten minutes left, O’Gara successfully converted from distance for 48 meters, reducing the gap to four points. Ireland held their nerve in injury time, with O’Gara delivering the winning drop goal from near the try line.

O'Gara kicked all his points—two were drops, five penalties to give them the victory. He's been great this season. In the first half, Pumas scored two tries early and got the first try of the game. Contepomi scored a couple goals there too.

Ireland won 21-19 against Argentina, with Ronan O'Gara scoring all his points to secure a perfect 100% record. The Pumas dominated early but lost two crucial penalties after rain and weather, forcing their defense to mount more pressure. Ireland scored twice in the first half, and Contepomi matched those penalties in the second half, though O'Gara made one last shot before being substituted. The final goal came when Contepomi missed, leaving Ireland just four points short.
tinyllama:1.1b: Irish rugby squad beat Argentina by 19-10 in their autumn international match held at Lansdowne Road stadium on Saturday. A late drop goal from Ronan O'Gara was enough to secure the win for Ireland, who had an impressive performance up until the final minutes. The game saw Argentina dominate early on with tries from Federico Arabinu and Felipe Contepi, but Ireland remained competitive thanks to Manuel Contepi's kicking display. Playing into a strong wind and rain, Irish rugby squad continued to come second-best in tight situations, resulting in turnovers accumulating against a rugged Argentina defence. The game ended with O'Gara landing two more penalties - one from 48 meters - to secure the win for Ireland. Despite conceding four points in the final minutes of play, it was a thrilling and fortuitous comeback that saw Ireland secure their place in the Rugby World Cup later this year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The match between Ireland and Argentina at the Lansdowne Road on Saturday turned into an intense encounter, with both teams putting up strong defensive efforts. However, in the second half, Ireland found themselves with a crucial chance to seize control of the game. They managed to score through Ronan O'Gara's penalty, taking the lead and making it look very certain. However, Argentina managed to equalize within minutes, giving the game a new dynamic and an exciting finish. This resulted in a thrilling finale that went into overtime. In the end, Ireland prevailed thanks to a superb drop goal from Ronan O'Gara. This victory extends their unbeaten run in their autumn internationals series and maintains the Pumas' 0% record thus far.
